text:
Welcome to howtocookthat.net I'm Ann Reardon
and today we are looking on how to use Chocolate
Transfer Sheets.

Chocolate transfer sheets have a designer
pattern in cocoa butter on a sheet that when

you then apply chocolate to it and peel it
off the pattern sticks to your chocolate.

It can look really good with a dessert but
if you use too much of it or too many patterns

on one dessert it starts to look a bit like
a zebra in striped pajamas so I'm gonna show

you how to use it to make your dessert look
classy.

Take your chocolate transfer sheet, cut a
thin strip, turn it so that it's the rough

side or the cocoa butter side up and then
apply chocolate over the top.

I've got some non-stick baking paper underneath
this so that any of the chocolate left over

we can peel it off and use it for something
else afterwards.

Spread it out in a thin even layer, and then
allow it to cool a little bit and set a little

bit and then lift it up and move it to a new
part of the sheet so that you have straight
edges along each side.

Next using your ruler, mark eight equal portions
so that we can make eight equal squares to
go the whole way around our dessert.

Then run a knife through your chocolate at
each of those divides and then allow to it
set.

For your curl on top, I'm not using the transfer
sheet because again I don't want too much
pattern just enough to make it look good.

So for the curl, spread out the chocolate
onto some plastic, draw a rectangle shape,

and then draw a straight line across the middle
so that you end up with two long triangles,

then bend it around and place it inside a
glass or a cup to hold it in a curved shape
and set that aside to set.

Once your chocolate squares are set, they
should just peel off the chocolate transfer

sheet and have the pattern that was on the
transfer sheet is now on your chocolate, so
place them around your dessert.

Grab the curls off the plastic and just split
them into two triangles and place one on top

of your dessert now this dessert is chocolate
cheese cake, I'll place the link to that recipe

Next we have a strawberry cheese cake with
a strip of white chocolate over the top.
I'm using stripey chocolate transfer sheet.

I am just trimming off the end bit that I
don't want, and then cutting one of the stripes
off.

Then place it cocoa butter side up so rough
side up on a piece of non-stick paper then

for this one I'm gonna use the white chocolate
and pour that over the top.

A lot of people ask what sort of chocolate
should I be using.

I've done a separate video explaining what
chocolate is the best chocolate to use for

your chocolate decorations so that will answer
your questions there.

Place the strip chocolate side down over your
dessert and trim it to the right length and
then leave that to set.

Once it is set firmly just peel off the acetate
plastic and then that leaves the loop there.

I've finished it off with some vanilla strawberries
which is just strawberries slow cooked with
some vanilla and a little bit of sugar.
We just pop those on the side.

And lastly I'll show you how to make the chocolate
sleeve to go around a dessert so you can do
that single sided or double sided.

Find something in your kitchen that has perpendicular
sides that goes straight up and down and then

wrap it in some non-stick paper or if you
want a double-sided design wrap it in your

chocolate transfer sheet then for the design
that I've showed you, I've got some plain

acetate with nothing on it and I'm using some
of that at the top, and then the pattern at
the bottom.

Because once again I like it with just a hint
of the pattern, not too much, i think that
looks a lot more classy.

Spread the chocolate over your vessel that
you've chosen, and then place it at one end,
and simply roll it up.

Once it's rolled around so that you can see
the top just push the end down onto the chocolate.

So that your ends are completely touching
and continue to roll it the whole way around

making sure it's lined up when you meet it
the other side and then just give it one more

roll to make sure it's smooth the whole way
around and then take a knife and run it along

the edge the top and the bottom and then leave
that to set.

Once it's set, gently ease the container that
you used out and those edges that you've cut
around should just fall off.

Pull down on the middle paper and take that
out again I'm just using non-stick baking

paper for that and then lastly peel off your
acetate sheet from your chocolate transfer

and the pattern stays on and you end up with
a pretty chocolate cuff that you can put over
the top of your dessert.

If you wanted to fill it with mousses something
like that you can make your chocolate disc

or circle and join it to that on the base
so that it's sealed, but in this case I'm

just gonna put it over the top of the dessert
and top it off with a strawberry.
Thanks for watching.

Don't forget to subscribe and put in your
comments below which one you would choose
to eat.
